1.0    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE
                         POLICIES (40 CFR 68.155(a))


The accidental release prevention policy for the Corning Incorporated, Midland, North Carolina Plant
(Corning Concord) involves a unified approach that integrates technology, procedures and
management practices.  Corning Concord's prevention program complies with all applicable U.S.
EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) Prevention Program regulations codified under 40 Code of
Federal Regulations (CFR) 68.

Manag

ement System

Corning-Concord maintains a management system to oversee the implementation of and compliance
with all elements of the RMP regulations.  This management system, along with other Corning-
Concord policies, provides a means to eliminate and/or reduce the potential for hazardous chemical
releases at the plant.

Prevention Program Level 3

Corning-Concord is a Program 3 facility.  Therefore, Corning-Concord's prevention program
provides for policies, procedures and systems that address all elements of the RMP concerning
Program Level 3 facilities and implementation procedures.  Corning-Concord's prevention program
also addresses the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety
Management (PSM) Program elements, which are similar to those required by the RMP regulations. 
The prevention program in place for the facility is maintained in Corning-Concord's Process
Information Management System (PIMS) document control system.
     2.0 STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
                       (40 CFR 68.155(b))


Site Description

The 155-acre Corning-Concord plant site is owned and operated by Corning Incorporated,
Telecommunications Products Division.  The site is located at 14556 Highway 601 South, Midland,
Cabarrus County, North Carolina.  The Corning-Concord plant currently employs 350 full-time
employees engaged in the manufacture of fiber optics.  At full production, which is expected by June
2000, the Corning-Concord plant will employ 650 full-time employees.

Regulated Substance

Chlorine is the only regulated substance at the plant that exceeds the threshold quantity listed in 40
CFR 68; therefore, chlorine is the only substance at the plant for which the RMP regulations apply. 
The chlorine storage and distribution system is contained in a specially designed process building. 
All chlorine utilized at the facility is contained within the Bulk Chlorine Storage Building that is
equipped with vent make up and exh

aust scrubber systems.   The chlorine process was installed as
part of the fiber optic manufacturing process.  Chlorine is received, stored and utilized in two (2)
processes that distribute chlorine to four (4) control panels. 

Chlorine is a halogen with the formula Cl2 and serves as a chlorinating or oxidizing agent.  Chlorine
is an Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and OSHA listed toxic chemical, an irritant, and a
corrosive substance. Chlorine is not a carcinogen or a flammable substance.  OSHA's ceiling
Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) for chlorine is 1 ppm.  The National Fire Protection Association
(NFPA) lists chlorine with a health rating of 4 (severe) with  immediate and delayed health hazards.

      3.0    WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS
                       (40 CFR 68.155(c))


Two (2) offsite consequence analyses were conducted which include two (2) chlorine release
scenarios.  The first is a "worst-case release". The second is a more probable "alternative release
scenario".  For the worst-case release scenario EPA states that "the facility shall assume that the
maximum quantity in a largest vessel is released as a gas over 10 minutes" due to a nonspecific
failure.  EPA defines the alternative release scenario as "more likely to occur than the worst-case
scenario".

The atmospheric dispersion modeling guidance developed by EPA in the Risk Management Program
Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants was used to determine the distance traveled by the
chlorine released before its concentration decreases to the "toxic endpoint".  The toxic endpoint for
chlorine was determined by EPA to be 0.0087 mg/l (3 ppm).  This concentration corresponds to the
Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2) and is defined by the American Industrial
Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the "maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that
nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing
irrevers

ible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to
take protective action".  The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the
toxic endpoint distance was defined, "to estimate the population potentially affected".

Worst-Case Release Scenario

The EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants, including all EPA
assumptions, was used to determine the toxic endpoint for the worst-case chlorine release scenario. 
Results indicate a distance to toxic endpoint of three (3) miles.  The estimated residential population
within a three (3) mile radius of the source that could potentially be affected by a release is 8,481. 
As well as residences, there are schools, doctor's offices, small businesses, and churches within the
three (3) mile radius of the source that could be potentially impacted by this release.

Alternative Release Scenario

The EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants, including all EPA
assumptions, was used to determine the toxic endpoint for the alternative-case chlorine release
scenario.  The alternative release scenario involves the rupture of the ," high pressure tubing
connected to one of the one ton containers.  Results indicate a distance to toxic endpoint of two tenth
(0.2) miles.  There are no residences that could potentially be affected by a release within the two
tenth (0.2) mile radius of the source.  No public or environmental receptors would be impacted by
this release.

Accidental Release Prevention Program

The Corning-Concord accidental release prevention program level to be Level 3 based on the OSHA
PSM program applicability to the facility.  The PSM program has been in place and effectively used
at the facility since April 26, 1999 and is part of the plant's operating culture. There are two (2) parts
to the program: 1) the general overall site program and 2) the chlorine specific actions within the site
program.  The

PSM program is coordinated with Cabarrus County Emergency Services (member of
the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC)) and the Midland Volunteer Fire Department.

    4.0   GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND
               CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
                       (40 CFR 68.155(d))
                                                 
General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Throughout the facility many elements of the prevention program are used for all operations. 
Overviews of the program are as follows.

Corning-Concord keeps detailed process safety information on all operations.
The PIMS document control system is an integral part of the management of change for all facility
  operations.
Employee training is ongoing in all plant areas and is the backbone of employee knowledge and job
  operations. Employee training in operations and maintenance provides an awareness of the
  hazardous and toxic properties of all chemicals used on-site.
Maintenance and preventative maintenance are implemented in all facility operations to ensure the
  mechanical integrity of each piece of equipment.
Incident investigations of accidents and potential accidents allow learning from each incident as well
  as provide corrective actions for each incident.
Employees participate in all aspects of the plant as listed under the Emergency Response Program.
Safe work practices used throughout the facility include Hot Work Permits, Lock-Out Tag-Out
  Permits, Vessel Entry Permits, Site Security, and Breaking Into Chemical Lines.
Contractors must meet Corning-Concord's high safety and technical standards as part of contractor
  selection and ongoing contractor evaluations.  Also, Corning-Concord requires training of
  contractors in their specific work locations. 

Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

Chemical specific prevention features of the Corning-Concord facility include those listed previously,
as well as, the following features specific to th

e chlorine process.

Specific response procedures for the operation of the chlorine building.
Completion of a Pre-startup Safety Review prior to the start up of the chlorine system.
Specific emergency response procedures for chlorine releases as provided under the Emergency
  Response Program.
Specific employee training in the properties, hazards, handling requirements, and leak repair for
  chlorine.
Knowledge and records of the facility and equipment design lead to the safe operations of the
  chlorine system.

Facility Design

The facility and support equipment of the chorine storage and control building meet and exceed
design code standards and good engineering practices.  The building is equipped with temperature
controls and make-up vents.  The building is operated under negative pressure created by the vent
scrubber.  There are two (2) modes of vent operations: normal and emergency.  In the event of a
chlorine release, the vent system doubles the air turnover through the building.

Equipment Design

The chlorine piping system is constructed of Hastelloy metal tubing.  This tubing is both compatible
with chlorine (non-corrosive) and rated to 1,500 psig.  The maximum pressure of the chlorine is only
150 psig allowing for a 10 to 1 safety margin.  There is a chlorine monitor that detects the presence
of chlorine in the storage building.  The monitor, along with other plant detection systems, will alarm
to alert employees of a potential chlorine release.
                5.0   FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
                       (40 CFR 68.155(e))
                                        
                                                 Per 40 CFR 67.42(s), no accidental releases of chlorine have occurred at the Corning-Concord site
over the last five (5) years.
                6.0   EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
                       (40 CFR 68.155(f))
                                                 

Emergency response procedures are contained in the facility's Conti

ngency Plan (Emergency Response Plan). 
The plan includes an emergency response "decision tree" and an emergency notification plan. 
Emergency response drills and drill evaluations are conducted once every month by the Operating
Department and once every quarter by the Safety Department.  Emergency operation and
response procedures are reviewed at each emergency response drill evaluation.

The Contingency/Emergency Response Plan is coordinated with and reviewed by Cabarrus County Emergency
Services (LEPC member) and the Midland Volunteer Fire Department.  Copies of the program
are given to local key agencies such as fire, medical, rescue, waste management and police
departments in Cabarrus County.  Aside from the specific contingency/emergency response plan,
key elements of the prevention programs are incorporated into the operating culture of the
Corning-Concord facility.

The Contingency/Emergency Response Plan procedures detail the actions and responses to releases of
chlorine.  The plan includes training of all operators in chlorine areas, a primary response team,
and a back-up response team.  Training is included for responding to catastrophic, severe, and
moderate releases of chlorine.  A Chlorine "B" Kit is maintained on site to stop leaks.

Personnel

Personnel are the key resource of Corning-Concord's prevention program.  Employees make up the operators
and emergency response teams.  Corning-Concord fosters a high level of involvement in every
aspect of chlorine system operations, including participation in the following.

Chlorine safety teams,
Development of the operating procedures,
Hazard evaluations, and
      On-going training of the operators and other involved staff.
           7.0    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
                 (40 CFR 68.155(g))
                                         

The Corning-Concord facility is a new facility that started manufacturing operations during the
summer of 1999.  To date, there have been no recommended act

ions on the current safety information
complying with the RMP and PSM programs.  Corning-Concord continually reviews implemented
and potential safety improvements for all its operations.
